channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: How can we make PhD training fit for the modern world? Broaden its philosophical foundations
item.content:encoded:

How can we make PhD training fit for the modern world? Broaden its philosophical foundations

item.title: Allow researchers with caring responsibilities ‘promotion pauses’ to make research more equitable
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00971-3

Allow researchers with caring responsibilities ‘promotion pauses’ to make research more equitable
item.dc:title: Allow researchers with caring responsibilities ‘promotion pauses’ to make research more equitable
item.dc:creator: Daniel H. Lowenstein

item.title: Long COVID still has no cure — so these patients are turning to research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00901-3

With key long COVID trials yet to yield results, people with the condition are trying to change how clinical trials are done.
item.dc:title: Long COVID still has no cure — so these patients are turning to research
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank

item.title: A 2023 hurricane caught Mexico off guard: we must work together to prepare better
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00904-0

Hurricane Otis yields lessons for researchers and policymakers on how to reduce risks in the face of inequality.
item.dc:title: A 2023 hurricane caught Mexico off guard: we must work together to prepare better

item.title: Cosmologist Claudia de Rham on falling for gravity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00903-1

The aspiring astronaut turned theoretical physicist talks travelling, the accelerating expansion of the Universe, thinking beyond three dimensions and detecting gravitational waves.
item.dc:title: Cosmologist Claudia de Rham on falling for gravity
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Green space near home has an antidepressant effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00968-y

People who had the most vegetation near their residences were the least likely to report depression and anxiety.
item.dc:title: Green space near home has an antidepressant effect

item.title: How I use tide gauges to develop geospatial maps
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00908-w

Geographer Muh Aris Marfai collects reference data for Indonesia’s coastal areas to prepare for the impacts of climate change.
item.dc:title: How I use tide gauges to develop geospatial maps
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: How scientists are making the most of Reddit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00906-y

As X wanes, researchers are turning to Reddit for insights and data, and to better connect with the public.
item.dc:title: How scientists are making the most of Reddit
item.dc:creator: Hannah Docter-Loeb

item.title: How synthetic biologists are building better biofactories
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00907-x

Artificial electron donors and acceptors expand researchers’ metabolic engineering options — if only cells would cooperate.
item.dc:title: How synthetic biologists are building better biofactories
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: The great rewiring: is social media really behind an epidemic of teenage mental illness?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00902-2

The evidence is equivocal on whether screen time is to blame for rising levels of teen depression and anxiety — and rising hysteria could distract us from tackling the real causes.
item.dc:title: The great rewiring: is social media really behind an epidemic of teenage mental illness?
item.dc:creator: Candice L. Odgers

item.title: Copper-catalyzed dehydrogenation or lactonization of C(sp<sup>3</sup>)−H bonds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07341-z

Copper-catalyzed dehydrogenation or lactonization of C(sp3)−H bonds
item.dc:title: Copper-catalyzed dehydrogenation or lactonization of C(sp<sup>3</sup>)−H bonds
item.dc:creator: Shupeng Zhou
Zi-Jun Zhang
Jin-Quan Yu

item.title: Scientists made a six-legged mouse embryo — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00943-7

A rodent with two extra limbs instead of genitals shows the crucial role of a gene pathway in determining the fate of a primordial structure.
item.dc:title: Scientists made a six-legged mouse embryo — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: How a spreadsheet helped me to land my dream job
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00950-8

A shared spreadsheet, passed from generation to generation, helps graduate students in management navigate the academic job market. Whatever your field of study, you can make one, too.
item.dc:title: How a spreadsheet helped me to land my dream job
item.dc:creator: Silvia Sanasi

item.title: The corpse of an exploded star and more — March’s best science images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00941-9

The month’s sharpest science shots, selected by Nature’s photo team.
item.dc:title: The corpse of an exploded star and more — March’s best science images
item.dc:creator: Emma Stoye

item.title: Sam Bankman-Fried sentencing: crypto-funded researchers grapple with FTX collapse
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00960-6

Organizations who received funds from FTX face pressure to return the money at significant operational cost.
item.dc:title: Sam Bankman-Fried sentencing: crypto-funded researchers grapple with FTX collapse
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O'Callaghan

item.title: This super-Earth is the first planet confirmed to have a permanent dark side
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00414-z

Convincing evidence of 1:1 tidal locking has been absent until a new analysis of the exoplanet LHS 3855b.
item.dc:title: This super-Earth is the first planet confirmed to have a permanent dark side
item.dc:creator: Joseph Howlett

item.title: Overcoming low vision to prove my abilities under pressure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00957-1

A genetic eye condition pushed biochemist Kamini Govender to develop coping strategies that serve her well in the lab and help her to avoid burnout.
item.dc:title: Overcoming low vision to prove my abilities under pressure
item.dc:creator: Lesley Evans Ogden

item.title: How papers with doctored images can affect scientific reviews
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00875-2

Scientists compiling a review scan more than 1,000 papers and find troubling images in nearly 20%.
item.dc:title: How papers with doctored images can affect scientific reviews
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni

item.title: Tweeting your research paper boosts engagement but not citations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00922-y

Analysis of a random selection of papers shared on social media showed no causative link between posting and citations.
item.dc:title: Tweeting your research paper boosts engagement but not citations
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Video: Cancer-busting vaccines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00842-x

Treatments that could train the immune system to identify and destroy cancer cells are on the way.
item.dc:title: Video: Cancer-busting vaccines

item.title: Cancer-vaccine trials give reasons for optimism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00840-z

Therapeutic vaccines could provide a transformative shot in the arm for cancer treatment.
item.dc:title: Cancer-vaccine trials give reasons for optimism
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: No sweat: Moisture-wicking device keeps wearable-tech dry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00945-5

Breathable patch could allow for comfortable and multifunctional wearable electronics.
item.dc:title: No sweat: Moisture-wicking device keeps wearable-tech dry
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: A global timekeeping problem postponed by global warming
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07170-0

Increased melting of ice in Greenland and Antarctica, measured by satellite gravity, has decreased the angular velocity of Earth more rapidly than before and has already affected global timekeeping.
item.dc:title: A global timekeeping problem postponed by global warming
item.dc:creator: Duncan Carr Agnew

item.title: CGRP sensory neurons promote tissue healing via neutrophils and macrophages
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07237-y

Experiments in mouse models show that NaV1.8+ nociceptors innervate sites of injury and provide wound repair signals to immune cells by releasing calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP).
item.dc:title: CGRP sensory neurons promote tissue healing via neutrophils and macrophages
item.dc:creator: Yen-Zhen Lu
Bhavana Nayer
Shailendra Kumar Singh
Yasmin K. Alshoubaki
Elle Yuan

Mikaël M. Martino

item.title: Formation of memory assemblies through the DNA-sensing TLR9 pathway
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07220-7

Learning results in persistent double-stranded DNA breaks, nuclear rupture and release of DNA fragments and histones within hippocampal CA1 neurons that, following TLR9-mediated DNA damage repair, results in their recruitment to memory circuits.
item.dc:title: Formation of memory assemblies through the DNA-sensing TLR9 pathway
item.dc:creator: Vladimir Jovasevic

item.title: The HEAT repeat protein HPO-27 is a lysosome fission factor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07249-8

The conserved HEAT repeat protein HPO-27 is identified as a lysosome scission factor in Caenorhabditis elegans, and the human homologue MROH1 also serves the same function to maintain lysosomal homeostasis.
item.dc:title: The HEAT repeat protein HPO-27 is a lysosome fission factor

item.title: Five million years of Antarctic Circumpolar Current strength variability
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07143-3

The strength of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current, as traced in sediment cores from the Pacific Southern Ocean, shows no linear long-term trend over the past 5.3 Myr; instead, the strongest flow occurs consistently in warmer-than-present intervals.
item.dc:title: Five million years of Antarctic Circumpolar Current strength variability

item.title: Optomechanical realization of the bosonic Kitaev chain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07174-w

We report the experimental realization of a bosonic Kitaev chain in a nano-optomechanical network.
item.dc:title: Optomechanical realization of the bosonic Kitaev chain
item.dc:creator: Jesse J. Slim
Clara C. Wanjura
Matteo Brunelli
Javier del Pino

item.title: TRBC1-targeting antibody–drug conjugates for the treatment of T cell cancers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07233-2

Anti-TRBC1 antibody–drug conjugates may offer a more potent T cell cancer therapy by bypassing the fratricide that may be limiting the efficacy of anti-TRBC1 CAR T cells in the clinical trial for patients with T cell cancers.
item.dc:title: TRBC1-targeting antibody–drug conjugates for the treatment of T cell cancers

item.title: Depleting myeloid-biased haematopoietic stem cells rejuvenates aged immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07238-x

Antibody-mediated depletion of myeloid-biased haematopoietic stem cells in aged mice restores characteristic features of a more youthful immune system.
item.dc:title: Depleting myeloid-biased haematopoietic stem cells rejuvenates aged immunity
item.dc:creator: Jason B. Ross
Lara M. Myers

item.title: Structural basis of exoribonuclease-mediated mRNA transcription termination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07240-3

A study presents two cryo-EM structures of yeast Pol II pre-termination transcription complexes bound to Rat1–Rai1, and provides the mechanisms for termination of mRNA transcription in yeast and other eukaryotes.
item.dc:title: Structural basis of exoribonuclease-mediated mRNA transcription termination
item.dc:creator: Yuan Zeng
Hong-Wei Zhang
Xiao-Xian Wu
Yu Zhang

item.title: High-fidelity spin qubit operation and algorithmic initialization above 1 K
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07160-2

Initialization and operation of spin qubits in silicon above 1 K reach fidelities sufficient for fault-tolerant operations at these temperatures.
item.dc:title: High-fidelity spin qubit operation and algorithmic initialization above 1 K

item.title: Controlling the helicity of light by electrical magnetization switching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07125-5

The helicity of light from a light-emitting diode can be electrically controlled by spin–orbit torque effects, enabling a seamless integration of magnetization dynamics with photonics.
item.dc:title: Controlling the helicity of light by electrical magnetization switching

item.title: Graphene nanoribbons grown in hBN stacks for high-performance electronics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07243-0

A strategy for the transfer-free direct growth of ultralong, high-quality graphene nanoribbons, which have desirable electronic properties, between layers of a boron nitride insulator is reported.
item.dc:title: Graphene nanoribbons grown in hBN stacks for high-performance electronics

item.title: A figure of merit for efficiency roll-off in TADF-based organic LEDs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07149-x

Efficiency roll-off in a wide range of TADF OLEDs is analysed and a figure of merit proposed for materials design to improve efficiency at high brightness, potentially expanding the range of applications of TADF materials.
item.dc:title: A figure of merit for efficiency roll-off in TADF-based organic LEDs
item.dc:creator: S. Diesing
L. Zhang
E. Zysman-Colman
I. D. W. Samuel

item.title: The complex polyploid genome architecture of sugarcane
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07231-4

We build a polyploid reference genome for hybrid sugarcane cultivar R570, improving on its current ‘mosaic monoploid’ representation, enabling fine-grain description of genome architecture and the exploration of candidate genes underlying the Bru1 brown rust resistance locus.
item.dc:title: The complex polyploid genome architecture of sugarcane

item.title: Targeting DCAF5 suppresses SMARCB1-mutant cancer by stabilizing SWI/SNF
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07250-1

DCAF5 has a quality-control function for SWI/SNF complexes and promotes the degradation of incompletely assembled SWI/SNF complexes in the absence of SMARCB1.
item.dc:title: Targeting DCAF5 suppresses SMARCB1-mutant cancer by stabilizing SWI/SNF

item.title: Climate velocities and species tracking in global mountain regions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07264-9

An analysis of the rate at which isotherms are shifting in mountain regions worldwide identifies 17 key regions with particularly high vertical isotherm shift velocities, and provides insight into how these shifts affect species ranges.
item.dc:title: Climate velocities and species tracking in global mountain regions
item.dc:creator: Wei-Ping Chan
Jonathan Lenoir
Guan-Shuo Mai
Hung-Chi Kuo
I-Ching Chen
Sheng-Feng Shen

item.title: Revealing uncertainty in the status of biodiversity change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07236-z

This study presents an approach to deal with spatial, temporal and phylogenetic non-independence in large-scale analyses of biodiversity change, improving trend estimation and inference across scales.
item.dc:title: Revealing uncertainty in the status of biodiversity change
item.dc:creator: T. F. Johnson

item.title: The complex circumstellar environment of supernova 2023ixf
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07116-6

Using ultraviolet data as well as a comprehensive set of further multiwavelength observations of the supernova 2023ixf, a reliable bolometric light curve is derived that indicates the heating nature of the early emission.
item.dc:title: The complex circumstellar environment of supernova 2023ixf

J. Wise
A. Wold
L. Yan
K. Zhang

item.title: Single-cell multiplex chromatin and RNA interactions in ageing human brain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07239-w

We introduce multinucleic acid interaction mapping in single cells (MUSIC), for concurrent profiling of multiplex chromatin interactions, gene expression and RNA–chromatin associations within individual nuclei, as a tool for exploring chromatin architecture and transcription.
item.dc:title: Single-cell multiplex chromatin and RNA interactions in ageing human brain
item.dc:creator: Xingzhao Wen
Zhifei Luo
Wenxin Zhao
Riccardo Calandrelli
Tri C. Nguyen
Xueyi Wan
John Lalith Charles Richard
Sheng Zhong

item.title: Heat and desiccation tolerances predict bee abundance under climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07241-2

A 16-year dataset of abundance patterns of a diverse assemblage of bees in New Mexico, USA predicts declines for many bee species and indicates that drought-tolerant taxa will prevail in a warming and drying climate.
item.dc:title: Heat and desiccation tolerances predict bee abundance under climate change
item.dc:creator: Melanie R. Kazenel
Karen W. Wright
Terry Griswold
Kenneth D. Whitney
Jennifer A. Rudgers

item.title: A three-dimensional liquid diode for soft, integrated permeable electronics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07161-1

Incorporation of a ‘liquid diode’ into a wearable electronic platform enhances comfort and stability by shunting away sweat as it accumulates.
item.dc:title: A three-dimensional liquid diode for soft, integrated permeable electronics
item.dc:creator: Binbin Zhang
Jiyu Li
Jingkun Zhou
Lung Chow

item.title: Interchain-expanded extra-large-pore zeolites
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07194-6

We report a strategy that yields thermally and hydrothermally stable silicates by expansion of a one-dimensional silicate chain with an intercalated silylating agent that separates and connects the chains.
item.dc:title: Interchain-expanded extra-large-pore zeolites
item.dc:creator: Zihao Rei Gao
Huajian Yu
Fei-Jian Chen
Alvaro Mayoral
Zijian Niu

item.title: Evidence for chiral graviton modes in fractional quantum Hall liquids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07201-w

Through inelastic light scattering chiral spin-2 long-wavelength magnetorotons are observed, revealing chiral graviton modes in fractional quantum Hall states and aiding in understanding the quantum metric impacts in topological correlated systems.
item.dc:title: Evidence for chiral graviton modes in fractional quantum Hall liquids
item.dc:creator: Jiehui Liang
Ziyu Liu
Zihao Yang
Yuelei Huang
Ursula Wurstbauer
Cory R. Dean
Ken W. West
Loren N. Pfeiffer
Lingjie Du
Aron Pinczuk

item.title: High-threshold and low-overhead fault-tolerant quantum memory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07107-7

An end-to-end quantum error correction protocol that implements fault-tolerant memory on the basis of a family of low-density parity-check codes shows the possibility of low-overhead fault-tolerant quantum memory within the reach of near-term quantum processors.
item.dc:title: High-threshold and low-overhead fault-tolerant quantum memory
item.dc:creator: Sergey Bravyi
Andrew W. Cross
Jay M. Gambetta
Dmitri Maslov
Patrick Rall
Theodore J. Yoder

item.title: A brainstem–hypothalamus neuronal circuit reduces feeding upon heat exposure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07232-3

In response to acute thermal challenge, thermosensing glutamatergic neurons of the parabrachial nucleus in mouse brain activate tanycytes, which reduce the excitability of Flt1-expressing dopamine and agouti-related peptide-containing neurons, thus suppressing appetite.
item.dc:title: A brainstem–hypothalamus neuronal circuit reduces feeding upon heat exposure
item.dc:creator: Marco Benevento
Alán Alpár
Anna Gundacker
Leila Afjehi
Kira Balueva
Zsofia Hevesi
János Hanics
Sabah Rehman
Daniela D. Pollak
Gert Lubec
Peer Wulff
Vincent Prevot
Tamas L. Horvath
Tibor Harkany

item.title: Thermonuclear explosions on neutron stars reveal the speed of their jets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07133-5

Relativistic jets observed from transient neutron stars throughout the Universe produce bright flares for minutes after each X-ray burst, helping to determine the role individual system properties have on the speed and revealing the dominant launching mechanism.
item.dc:title: Thermonuclear explosions on neutron stars reveal the speed of their jets
item.dc:creator: Thomas D. Russell
Nathalie Degenaar
Jakob van den Eijnden
Thomas Maccarone
Alexandra J. Tetarenko
Celia Sánchez-Fernández
James C. A. Miller-Jones
Erik Kuulkers
Melania Del Santo

item.title: Daily briefing: Tweeting about your paper doesn’t boost citations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00958-0

Posting about a paper on X seems to boost engagement but not citations. Plus, researchers pinpoint humans’ first home outside Africa and what the science says about the Baltimore bridge collapse.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Tweeting about your paper doesn’t boost citations
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Journal editors are resigning en masse: what do these group exits achieve?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00887-y

Editorial rebellions seem to be on the rise, as researchers seek more control over scholarly communication.
item.dc:title: Journal editors are resigning en masse: what do these group exits achieve?
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Electrons flip a switch on optical communications
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00663-y

Clever manipulation of electrons has enabled scientists to change a key property of light emitted by a device using electrically controlled magnetization. The method could lead to stable and energy-efficient information transfer.
item.dc:title: Electrons flip a switch on optical communications
item.dc:creator: Satoshi Hiura

item.title: The real time-travel paradox was the friends we made along the way
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00897-w

Life at the cutting edge.
item.dc:title: The real time-travel paradox was the friends we made along the way
item.dc:creator: Rodrigo Culagovski

item.title: Climate change has slowed Earth’s rotation — and could affect how we keep time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00932-w

The effect of melting polar ice could delay the need for a ‘leap second’ by three years.
item.dc:title: Climate change has slowed Earth’s rotation — and could affect how we keep time
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Divisive Sun-dimming study at Harvard cancelled: what’s next?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00876-1

As the climate crisis rages on, advocacy for testing controversial solar geoengineering technology is ramping up.
item.dc:title: Divisive Sun-dimming study at Harvard cancelled: what’s next?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: The surprising history of the Southern Ocean’s super current
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00678-5

Reconstructions of the strength of a powerful current that circles the South Pole reveal that it has undergone no long-term change in the past five million years, even though Earth cooled substantially over that time.
item.dc:title: The surprising history of the Southern Ocean’s super current
item.dc:creator: Natalie J. Burls

item.title: Anti-ageing antibodies revive the immune system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00680-x

Depleting an expanding pool of aberrant stem cells in aged mice using antibody therapy has been shown to rebalance blood cell production, diminish age-associated inflammation and strengthen acquired immune responses.
item.dc:title: Anti-ageing antibodies revive the immune system
item.dc:creator: Yasar Arfat T. Kasu
Robert A. J. Signer

item.title: Maple-scented cacti and pom-pom cats: how pranking at work can lift lab spirits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00951-7

Whether for April Fools’ Day or year-round, practical jokes allow scientists to tap into creative thinking while building group camaraderie.
item.dc:title: Maple-scented cacti and pom-pom cats: how pranking at work can lift lab spirits
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: The wearable electronic patch that’s impervious to sweat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00789-z

A smart adhesive patch that wicks sweat away from electronics embedded in its centre offers comfortable and reliable sensing of the wearer’s biometrics or environment without the risk of perspiration damaging the devices.
item.dc:title: The wearable electronic patch that’s impervious to sweat
item.dc:creator: Yifan Rao
Nanshu Lu

item.title: How to make an old immune system young again
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00871-6

Antibodies that target blood stem cells can rejuvenate immune responses in mice.
item.dc:title: How to make an old immune system young again
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Mouse brains respond differently to observed threat and direct danger
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00051-6

Humans and other social animals are highly adept at learning by observing how others interact with the environment, especially when identifying potential sources of danger. In mice, a specific brain region acts as an information-processing hub that distinguishes between observed and directly experienced fear, and signals different behavioural responses accordingly.
item.dc:title: Mouse brains respond differently to observed threat and direct danger

item.title: Memories are made by breaking DNA — and fixing it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00930-y

Nerve cells form long-term memories with the help of an inflammatory response, study in mice finds.
item.dc:title: Memories are made by breaking DNA — and fixing it
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Melting ice solves leap-second problem — for now
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00850-x

Humans’ effect on the polar ice sheets is slowing Earth’s rotation, posing challenges for its alignment with the official time standard. Two researchers discuss the science behind the slowdown and the impact it has on timekeeping.
item.dc:title: Melting ice solves leap-second problem — for now
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Tavella
Jerry X. Mitrovica

item.title: Innate immunity in neurons makes memories persist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00679-4

A population of neurons that engages mechanisms of the innate immune system during memory formation has been uncovered in mice. Surprisingly, inflammatory signalling might pave the way for long-term memory.
item.dc:title: Innate immunity in neurons makes memories persist
item.dc:creator: Benjamin A. Kelvington
Ted Abel

item.title: How does a cancer vaccine work?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00841-y

After decades of slow progress, therapeutic vaccines that direct the immune system to attack tumours could soon become a fixture of cancer treatment.
item.dc:title: How does a cancer vaccine work?
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: Climate change predicted to exacerbate declines in bee populations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00681-w

What effects will climate change have on insect communities? Analyses of data collected over decades robustly document consequences specific to bee populations, and this evidence might aid future conservation efforts.
item.dc:title: Climate change predicted to exacerbate declines in bee populations
item.dc:creator: Nicole E. Miller-Struttmann

item.title: How climate change is affecting global timekeeping
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00952-6

Melting polar ice could delay major time adjustment, and the strange connection between brain inflammation and memory.
item.dc:title: How climate change is affecting global timekeeping
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Nature is committed to diversifying its journalistic sources
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00891-2

The latest data are in on the diversity of people interviewed for the journal’s News, Features and Careers articles, and audio and video content.
item.dc:title: Nature is committed to diversifying its journalistic sources

item.title: The race to uncover fission factors for lysosomal organelles heats up
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00851-w

Organelles called lysosomes fuse with cargo-carrying vesicles and degrade the cargo molecules. How lysosomes maintain their size despite constant vesicle fusion was unclear, but now factors that aid organelle fission have been found.
item.dc:title: The race to uncover fission factors for lysosomal organelles heats up
item.dc:creator: Shilpa Gopan
Thomas J. Pucadyil

item.title: Superconductivity case shows the need for zero tolerance of toxic lab culture
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00915-x

Superconductivity case shows the need for zero tolerance of toxic lab culture
item.dc:title: Superconductivity case shows the need for zero tolerance of toxic lab culture
item.dc:creator: Juan Pablo Fuenzalida Werner

item.title: How Sydney Harbour Bridge was shaping up 100 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00684-7

Plans for Sydney’s iconic landmark become concrete, plus a ‘Michelin Guide’ to superconductive tunnelling, in the weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: How Sydney Harbour Bridge was shaping up 100 years ago

item.title: These levitating bubbles are long-lived and puncture-proof
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00859-2

Soap bubbles bombarded with ultrasonic waves rise into mid-air and can survive being stabbed with a needle.
item.dc:title: These levitating bubbles are long-lived and puncture-proof

item.title: Cuts to postgraduate funding threaten Brazilian science — again
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00916-w

Cuts to postgraduate funding threaten Brazilian science — again
item.dc:title: Cuts to postgraduate funding threaten Brazilian science — again
item.dc:creator: Marcus F. Oliveira
Adriane R. Todeschini
